Itâ€™s easy to feel overwhelmed by lifeâ€™s tasks, but how we approach them can change everything.

Hereâ€™s a small shift that can have a big impact:
Instead of saying â€œI have to,â€ try saying â€œI get to.â€

This simple change can transform your daily responsibilities into opportunities for growth and gratitude.

When you say â€œI get to,â€ youâ€™re embracing the opportunity to:
ï¸ Show up with intention.
ï¸ Appreciate the simple things.
ï¸ Cultivate positivity and joy.

Shifting our mindset isnâ€™t always easy, but itâ€™s a choice we can make every day.

By framing tasks as privileges, we move from feeling burdened to feeling empowered.

 Tell me in the commentsâ€”how will you use this shift in your life today?
ï¸ Share this to inspire someone else to reframe their mindset.
 Follow me for more insights on building a positive and fulfilling life.

comments.commentText:
And remember: every task, big or small, contributes to the bigger picture of your life.
ï¸ That email you 'get to' send might build a connection.
ï¸ That workout you 'get to' do strengthens your body and mind.
ï¸ That job you 'get to' show up for supports your dreams.
Small shifts lead to massive changes over time.
 The mindset of gratitude isnâ€™t just a practiceâ€”itâ€™s a superpower.

posts.name:
Steve Litzow
Steve Litzow
posts.content:
Big deal about to close... but itâ€™s not the ICP?

When I work on refining sales strategies for scale ups, I always include a validation step.

It comes after the proposal and negotiation.

Itâ€™s an internal step for:
â€“ The CEO or VP of Sales to review the deal.
â€“ The SDR or sales manager to self-analyze.
â€“ An item to discuss during weekly or monthly deal reviews.

The key focus of validation?

Double-check the customer still fits your ICP.

Itâ€™s overlooked because:
â€“ The SDR wants to hit quota.
â€“ The sales manager wants to hit quota.
â€“ Or simply, the revenue is too tempting to resist.

But if youâ€™re serious about scaling to 8 or 9 figures, you must take this step.

You must reconsider going ahead if the ICP isnâ€™t the right fit.

Hereâ€™s whyâ€¦

I recently read a story from Jake Fuentes, co-founder of Cascade, about why he shut his startup down.

He admitted that â€œICP frayâ€ was a key factor.

Cascade initially defined their ICP as â€œnontechnical business analysts using Excel to crunch big data setsâ€.

The definition was too broad.

They ended up chasing customers with wildly different use cases:
â€“ A scooter company managing location data.
â€“ An HR team managing employee data.

They didnâ€™t have a framework to accept or reject opportunities, so they tried to support them all.

Jake described this as â€œa slow death of a thousand cuts.â€

Supporting anyone and everyone pulled the company in a million directions, ultimately diluting their focus and stunting growth.

If you want to scale successfully, rejecting deals from prospects who donâ€™t fit your ICP is the tough but necessary way forward.

Validate every deal.

Stick to your guns.

Keep closing.

Like what you read? ï¸ Repost it to your network and follow Steve Litzow for more.

Want to accelerate your sales? Join our community of CEOs & Sales Leaders subscribers today:

comments.commentText: Staying true to your ICP is crucial for growth. Misaligned deals might boost short-term revenue but often lead to inefficiencies and lost focus. Discipline here pays dividends!

Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
posts.content:
Workflow Automation Guide: Put Your Work on Autopilot

1. What is Workflow Automation?
Workflow automation combines sequential tasks with technology to minimize human input and maximize efficiency.

2. Why Automate Your Workflows?
Save time, boost productivity, improve accuracy, and scale operations efficiently without adding extra resources.

3. Examples of Workflow Automation
From sales lead management to automating HR onboarding, workflow automation supports various business functions seamlessly.

4. How to Get Started
Identify repetitive workflows, select the right tools like Make, customize processes with logic and integrations, and scale gradually.

[Explore more in the post]

posts.name:
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
posts.content:
â€œScripts Are A Waste Of Time.â€

FALSE

Scripts should NOT be read word for word. (After all, actors are paid VERY good money to read a script well.)

Scripts should create consistency and provide a framework for success.

A good script guides the conversation, ensuring key points are covered while allowing room for personalization and natural flow.

The alternative to having a script? Chaos. Without structure, your sales floor becomes the Wild West, where every rep makes it up as they go.

Scripts ensure everyone is aligned, the message is clear, and prospects feel understood â€“ not overwhelmed.

If you want a sales team that is focused, confident, and effective â€“ start by embracing the power of a great script.

comments.commentText: Scripts ensure you hit the main points, I tend to refer to mine as outlines so there is no confusion.
